The Recession of 1981-1982 is recognized as one of the most severe economic downturns in the United States following World War II, coming on the heels of a brief recession in 1980. Triggered by high inflation and rising interest rates—peaking at around 20 percent—the economy faced significant declines in consumer spending and industrial production. By the end of the recession in November 1982, unemployment had surged to twelve million, with marked increases in manufacturing and construction [...] The high interest rates were responsible for a sharp decline in purchases of new homes and automobiles. Consumer spending on such items as furniture and household equipment (durable goods) as well as home construction is responsive to interest rates. These expenditure declines were major causes of the sixteen-month recession that began in July, 1981, and resulted in an increase in unemployment to the highest levels since 1941.
